name: ADVr_SLT
long_name: Vertical advective flux of salinity
comments_1: Vertical advective flux of salinity (SALT) in the +z direction through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVr_SLT(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z fluxes through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: ADVr_TH
long_name: Vertical advective flux of potential temperature
comments_1: Vertical advective flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +z direction through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVr_TH(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z fluxes through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: ADVx_SLT
long_name: Lateral advective flux of salinity in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of salinity (SALT) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVx_SLT(i_g,j,k) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: ADVx_TH
long_name: Lateral advective flux of potential temperature in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVx_TH(i_g,j,k) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's lat-lon-cap (llc) curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: ADVxHEFF
long_name: Lateral advective flux of sea-ice thickness in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of grid cell mean sea-ice thickness (HEFF) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVxHEFF(i_g,j) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: ADVxSNOW
long_name: Lateral advective flux of snow thickness in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of grid cell mean snow thickness (HSNOW) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVxSNOW(i_g,j) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: ADVy_SLT
long_name: Lateral advective flux of salinity in the model +y direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of salinity (SALT) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVy_SLT(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: ADVy_TH
long_name: Lateral advective flux of potential temperature in the model +y direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVy_TH(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: ADVyHEFF
long_name: Lateral advective flux of sea-ice thickness in the model +y direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of grid cell mean sea-ice thickness (HEFF) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVyHEFF(i,j_g) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: ADVySNOW
long_name: Lateral advective flux of snow thickness in the model +y direction
comments_1: Lateral advective flux of grid cell mean snow thickness (HSNOW) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +ADVySNOW(i,j_g) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: DFrE_SLT
long_name: Vertical diffusive flux of salinity (explicit term)
comments_1: The explicit term of the vertical diffusive flux of salinity (SALT) in the +z direction through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid. In the ECCO V4r4 model, an implicit scheme is used to calculate vertical diffusive tracer fluxes due to background diffusivity and the Kwz component of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of vertical gradient) while an explicit scheme is used to calculate the vertical diffusive fluxes from the Kwx and Kwy components of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of horizontal gradient). Both implicit and explicit components of vertical diffusive flux of salinity are provided.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFrE_SLT(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z fluxes through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: DFrE_TH
long_name: Vertical diffusive flux of potential temperature (explicit term)
comments_1: The explicit term of the vertical diffusive flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +z direction through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid. In the ECCO V4r4 model, an implicit scheme is used to calculate vertical diffusive tracer fluxes due to background diffusivity and the Kwz component of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of vertical gradient) while an explicit scheme is used to calculate the vertical diffusive fluxes from the Kwx and Kwy components of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of horizontal gradient). Both implicit and explicit components of vertical diffusive flux of potential temperature are provided.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFrE_TH(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z fluxes through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: DFrI_SLT
long_name: Vertical diffusive flux of salinity (implicit term)
comments_1: The implicit term of the vertical diffusive flux of salinity (SALT) in the +z direction through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid. In the ECCO V4r4 model, an implicit scheme is used to calculate vertical diffusive tracer fluxes due to background diffusivity and the Kwz component of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of vertical gradient) while an explicit scheme is used to calculate the vertical diffusive fluxes from the Kwx and Kwy components of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of horizontal gradient). Both implicit and explicit components of vertical diffusive flux of salinity are provided.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFrI_SLT(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z fluxes through the top face 'w' of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: DFrI_TH
long_name: Vertical diffusive flux of potential temperature (implicit term)
comments_1: The implicit term of the vertical diffusive flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +z direction through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid. In the ECCO V4r4 model, an implicit scheme is used to calculate vertical diffusive tracer fluxes due to background diffusivity and the Kwz component of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of vertical gradient) while an explicit scheme is used to calculate the vertical diffusive fluxes from the Kwx and Kwy components of the GM-Redi tensor (vertical flux as a function of horizontal gradient). Both implicit and explicit components of vertical diffusive flux of potential temperature are provided.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFrI_TH(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z fluxes through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: DFxE_SLT
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of salinity in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of salinity (SALT) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFxE_SLT(i_g,j,k) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: DFxE_TH
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of potential temperature in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFxE_TH(i_g,j,k) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: DFxEHEFF
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of sea-ice thickness in the model +x direction.
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of grid cell mean sea-ice thickness (HEFF) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFxEHEFF(i_g,j) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: DFxESNOW
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of snow thickness in the model +x direction
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of grid cell mean snow thickness (HSNOW) in the +x direction through the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFxESNOW(i_g,j) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: DFyE_SLT
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of salinity in the model +y direction
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of salinity (SALT) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFyE_SLT(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. Salinity defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: DFyE_TH
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of potential temperature in the model +y direction.
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of potential temperature (THETA) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFyE_TH(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: DFyEHEFF
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of sea-ice thickness in the model +y direction.
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of grid cell mean sea-ice thickness (HEFF) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFyEHEFF(i,j_g) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: DFyESNOW
long_name: Lateral diffusive flux of snow thickness in the model +y direction
comments_1: Lateral diffusive flux of grid cell mean snow thickness (HSNOW) in the +y direction through the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal flux quantities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +DFyESNOW(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: DIFFKR
long_name: Vertical diffusivity
comments_1: Background vertical diffusion coefficient for temperature and salinity. Total vertical diffusivity includes background diffusivity plus contributions from the GGL90 vertical mixing and the Gent-McWilliams/Redi parameterizations.
comments_2: Note: DIFFKR is a model control variable and has been optimized from a spatially-invariant first-guess value of 1e-5 m2 s-1.

name: DRHODR
long_name: Density stratification
comments_1: Density stratification: d(sigma) d z-1
comments_2: Note: density computations are done with in-situ density. The vertical derivatives of in-situ density and locally-referenced potential density are identical  The equation of state is a modified UNESCO formula by Jackett and McDougall (1995), which uses the model variable potential temperature as input assuming a horizontally and temporally constant pressure of $p_0=-g ho_{0} z$.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > DENSITY
internal note: is stratification calculated on z* or z coordinates?

name: ETAN
long_name: Model sea level anomaly
comments_1: Model sea level anomaly WITHOUT corrections for global mean density (steric) changes, inverted barometer effect, or volume displacement due to submerged sea-ice and snow
comments_2: Note: ETAN should NOT be used for comparisons with altimetry data products because ETAN is NOT corrected for (a) global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH) nor (b) sea level displacement due to submerged sea-ice and snow (see sIceLoad). These corrections ARE made for the variables SSH and SSHNOIBC.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SEA SURFACE TOPOGRAPHY > SEA SURFACE HEIGHT

name: EXFaqh
long_name: Atmosphere surface (2 m) specific humidity
comments_1: Surface (2 m) specific humidity over open water
comments_2: Note: sum of ERA-Interim surface specific humidity and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > ATMOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR > WATER VAPOR INDICATORS > HUMIDITY > SPECIFIC HUMIDITY

name: EXFatemp
long_name: Atmosphere surface (2 m) air temperature
comments_1: Surface (2 m) air temperature over open water
comments_2: Note: sum of ERA-Interim surface air temperature and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > ATMOSPHERIC TEMPERATURE > SURFACE TEMPERATURE > AIR TEMPERATURE

name: EXFempmr
long_name: Open ocean net surface freshwater flux from precipitation, evaporation, and runoff
comments_1: Net surface freshwater flux from precipitation, evaporation, and runoff per unit area in open water (not covered by sea-ice). Excludes freshwater fluxes involving sea-ice and snow.
comments_2: Note: calculated as EXFevap-EXFpreci-EXFroff.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > FRESH WATER FLUX

name: EXFevap
long_name: Open ocean evaporation rate
comments_1: Evaporation rate per unit area of open water (not covered by sea-ice).
comments_2: Note: calculated using the bulk formula following Large and Yeager (2004) NCAR/TN-460+STR.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > ATMOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR > WATER VAPOR PROCESSES > EVAPORATION

name: EXFhl
long_name: Open ocean air-sea latent heat flux
comments_1: Air-sea latent heat flux per unit area of open water (not covered by sea-ice).
comments_2: Note: calculated from the bulk formula following Large and Yeager (2004) NCAR/TN-460+STR.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > EVAPORATION

name: EXFhs
long_name: Open ocean air-sea sensible heat flux
comments_1: Air-sea sensible heat flux per unit area of open water (not covered by sea-ice).
comments_2: Note: calculated from the bulk formula following Large and Yeager (2004) NCAR/TN-460+STR.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: EXFlwdn
long_name: Downward longwave radiative flux
comments_1: Downward longwave radiative flux
comments_2: Note: sum of ERA-Interim downward longwave radiation and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > LONGWAVE RADIATION

name: EXFlwnet
long_name: Net open ocean longwave radiative flux
comments_1: Net longwave radiative flux per unit area of open water (not covered by sea-ice).
comments_2: Note: net longwave radiation over open water calculated from downward longwave radiation (EXFlwdn) and upward longwave radiation from ocean and sea-ice thermal emission (Stefan-Boltzman law).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > LONGWAVE RADIATION

name: EXFpreci
long_name: Precipitation rate
comments_1: Precipitation rate
comments_2: Note: sum of ERA-Interim precipitation and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > PRECIPITATION > PRECIPITATION RATE > SURFACE PRECIPITATION

name: EXFpress
long_name: Atmosphere surface pressure
comments_1: Atmospheric pressure field at sea level
comments_2: Note: ERA-Interim atmospheric pressure, with air tides removed using a variety of methods. Not adjusted by the ocean state estimation.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE > SEA LEVEL PRESSURE

name: EXFqnet
long_name: Open ocean net air-sea heat flux
comments_1: Net air-sea heat flux (turbulent and radiative) per unit area of open water (not covered by sea-ice).
comments_2: Note: net upward heat flux over open water, calculated as EXFlwnet+EXFswnet-EXFlh-EXFhs.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: EXFroff
long_name: River runoff
comments_1: River runoff freshwater flux
comments_2: Note: not adjusted by the optimization.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > TERRESTRIAL HYDROSPHERE > SURFACE WATER > SURFACE WATER PROCESSES/MEASUREMENTS > RUNOFF > RUNOFF RATE

name: EXFswdn
long_name: Downwelling shortwave radiative flux
comments_1: Downward shortwave radiative flux
comments_2: Note: sum of ERA-Interim downward shortwave radiation and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > SHORTWAVE RADIATION

name: EXFswnet
long_name: Open ocean net shortwave radiative flux
comments_1: Net shortwave radiative flux per unit area of open water (not covered by sea-ice).
comments_2: Note: net shortwave radiation over open water calculated from downward shortwave flux (EXFswdn) and ocean surface albdeo.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > SHORTWAVE RADIATION

name: EXFtaux
long_name: Wind stress in the model +x direction
comments_1: Wind stress in the +x direction at the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: EXFtaux is the stress applied to the ice-free ocean surface and sea-ice covered surface. When sea-ice is present, the total stress applied to the ocean surface in the +x direction is NOT EXFtaux, but a combination of EXFtaux wind stress in the open water fraction and a stress from sea-ice in the ice-covered fraction (see oceTAUX). EXFtaux is the sum of ERA-Interim stress and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
direction: >0 increases horizontal velocity in the +x direction (UVEL)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > WIND STRESS

name: EXFtauy
long_name: Wind stress in the model +y direction
comments_1: Wind stress in the +y direction at the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: EXFtauy is the stress applied to the ice-free ocean surface and sea-ice covered surface. When sea-ice is present, the total stress applied to the ocean surface in the +y direction is NOT EXFtauy, but a combination of EXFtauy wind stress in the open water fraction and a stress from sea-ice in the ice-covered fraction (see oceTAUY). EXFtaux is the sum of ERA-Interim stress and the control adjustment from ocean state estimation.
direction: >0 increases horizontal velocity in the +y direction (VVEL)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > WIND STRESS

name: EXFuwind
long_name: Wind speed at 10m in the model +x direction
comments_1: Wind speed at 10m in the +x direction at the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: ECCO v4r4 is forced with wind stress (see EXFtaux) not vector winds converted to wind stress using bulk formulae. EXFuwind is calculated by converting wind stress to vector wind using bulk formulae.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > SURFACE WINDS

name: EXFvwind
long_name: Wind speed at 10m in the model +y direction
comments_1: Wind speed at 10m in the +y direction at the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: ECCO v4r4 is forced with wind stress (see EXFtauy) not vector winds converted to wind stress using bulk formulae. EXFvwind is calculated by converting wind stress to vector wind using bulk formulae.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > SURFACE WINDS

name: EXFwspee
long_name: Wind speed
comments_1: 10-m wind speed magnitude (>= 0 ) over open water. Only used for the calculation of air-sea fluxes using bulk formulae.
comments_2: Note: not adjusted by the ocean state estimation and not necesarily consistent with EXFuwind and EXFvwind because EXFuwind and EXFvwind are calculated from EXFtaux and EXFtauy using bulk formulae. EXFwspee != sqrt(EXFuwind**2 + EXFvwind**2.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > SURFACE WINDS, EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > ATMOSPHERIC WINDS > SURFACE WINDS > WIND SPEED

name: GM_PsiX
long_name: Gent-Mcwilliams bolus transport streamfunction in the model +x direction
comments_1: Gent-Mcwilliams bolus transport streamfunction 'u' component
comments_2: any comments welcome
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION

name: GM_PsiY
long_name: Gent-Mcwilliams bolus transport streamfunction in the model +y direction
comments_1: Gent-Mcwilliams bolus transport streamfunction 'v' component
comments_2: any comments welcome
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION

name: KAPGM
long_name: Gent-McWilliams diffusivity
comments_1: Gent-McWilliams diffusivity coefficient as described in Gent and McWilliams (1990, JPO)
comments_2: Note: KAPGM is a model control variable and has been optimized from a spatially invariant first guess of 1e3 m2 s-1.

name: KAPREDI
long_name: Along-isopycnal diffusivity
comments_1: Redi along-isopycnal diffusivity coefficient as described in Redi (1982, JPO)
comments_2: Note: KAPREDI is a model control variable and has been optimized from a spatially invariant first guess of 1e3 m2 s-1.

name: MXLDEPTH
long_name: Mixed-layer depth diagnosed using the temperature difference criterion of Kara et al., 2000
comments_1: Mixed-layer depth as determined by the depth where waters are first 0.8 degrees Celsius colder than the surface. See Kara et al. (JGR, 2000).
comments_2: Note: the Kara et al. criterion may not be appropriate for some applications. If needed, mixed layer depth can be calculated using different criteria. See vertical density stratification (DRHODR) and density anomaly (RHOAnoma).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN MIXED LAYER

name: OBP
long_name: Ocean bottom pressure given as equivalent water thickness
comments_1: OBP excludes the contribution from global mean atmospheric pressure and is therefore suitable for comparisons with GRACE data products
comments_2: OBP is calculated as follows. First, we calculate ocean hydrostatic bottom pressure anomaly, PHIBOT, with PHIBOT = p_b/rhoConst - gH(t), where p_b = model ocean hydrostatic bottom pressure, rhoConst = reference density (1029 kg m-3), g is acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m s-2), and H(t) is model depth at time t. Then, OBP = PHIBOT/g + corrections for i) global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH) and ii) global mean atmospheric pressure variations. Use OBP for comparisons with ocean bottom pressure data products that have been corrected for global mean atmospheric pressure variations. GRACE data typically ARE corrected for global mean atmospheric pressure variations. In contrast, ocean bottom pressure gauge data typically ARE NOT corrected for global mean atmospheric pressure variations.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE > WATER PRESSURE

name: OBPGMAP
long_name: Ocean bottom pressure given as equivalent water thickness, includes global mean atmospheric pressure
comments_1: OBPGMAP includes the contribution from global mean atmospheric pressure and is therefore suitable for comparisons with ocean bottom pressure gauge data products.
comments_2: OBPGMAP is calculated as follows. First, we calculate ocean hydrostatic bottom pressure anomaly, PHIBOT, with PHIBOT = p_b/rhoConst - gH(t), where p_b = model ocean hydrostatic bottom pressure, rhoConst = reference density (1029 kg m-3), g is acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m s-2), and H(t) is model depth at time t. Then, OBPGMAP= PHIBOT/g + corrections for global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH). Use OBPGMAP for comparisons with ocean bottom pressure data products that have NOT been corrected for global mean atmospheric pressure variations. GRACE data typically ARE corrected for global mean atmospheric pressure variations. In contrast, ocean bottom pressure gauge data typically ARE NOT corrected for global mean atmospheric pressure variations.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE > WATER PRESSURE

name: oceFWflx
long_name: Net freshwater flux into the ocean
comments_1: Net freshwater flux into the ocean including contributions from runoff, evaporation, precipitation, and mass exchange with sea-ice due to melting and freezing and snow melting
comments_2: Note: oceFWflx does NOT include freshwater fluxes between the atmosphere and sea-ice and snow. The variable 'SIatmFW' accounts for freshwater fluxes out of the combined ocean+sea-ice+snow reservoir.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > FRESH WATER FLUX

name: oceQnet
long_name: Net heat flux into the ocean surface
comments_1: Net heat flux into the ocean surface from all processes: air-sea turbulent and radiative fluxes and turbulent and conductive fluxes between the ocean and sea-ice and snow.
comments_2: Note: oceQnet does not include the change in ocean heat content due to changing ocean ocean mass (oceFWflx). Mass fluxes from evaporation, precipitation, and runoff (EXFempmr) happen at the same temperature as the ocean surface temperature. Consequently, EmPmR does not change ocean surface temperature. Conversely, mass fluxes due to sea-ice thickening/thinning and snow melt in the model are assumed to happen at a fixed 0C. Consequently, mass fluxes due to phase changes between seawater and sea-ice and snow induce a heat flux when the ocean surface temperaure is not 0C. The variable TFLUX does include the change in ocean heat content due to changing ocean mass.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: oceQsw
long_name: Net shortwave radiative flux across the ocean surface
comments_1: Net shortwave radiative flux across the ocean surface
comments_2: Note: Shortwave radiation penetrates below the surface grid cell.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > SHORTWAVE RADIATION

name: oceSPDep
long_name: Salt plume depth
comments_1: Depth of parameterized salt plumes formed due to brine rejection during sea-ice formation.

name: oceSPflx
long_name: Net salt flux into the ocean due to brine rejection
comments_1: Net salt flux into the ocean due to brine rejection during sea-ice formation.
comments_2: Note: units are grams of salt per square meter per second, not salinity per square meter per second.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: oceSPtnd
long_name: Salt tendency due to the vertical transport of salt in high-salinity brine plumes
comments_1: Salt tendency due to the vertical transport of salt in high-salinity brine plumes
comments_2: Note: units are grams of salt per square meter per second, not salinity per square meter per second.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALT TRANSPORT

name: oceTAUX
long_name: Ocean surface stress in the model +x direction
comments_1: Ocean surface stress due to wind and sea-ice in the +x direction centered over the 'u' side of the the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, wind stress acts on horizontal velocities which are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +oceTAUX(i_g,j) corresponds to +x momentum fluxes at 'u' edge of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
direction: >0 increases horizontal velocity in the +x direction (UVEL)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > WIND STRESS

name: oceTAUY
long_name: Ocean surface stress in the model +y direction
comments_1: Ocean surface stress due to wind and sea-ice in the +y direction centered over the 'v' side of the the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, wind stress acts on horizontal velocities which are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +oceTAUY(i_g,j) corresponds to +y momentum fluxes at 'v' edge of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
direction: >0 increases horizontal velocity in the +y direction (VVEL)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN WINDS > WIND STRESS

name: PHIBOT
long_name: Ocean hydrostatic bottom pressure anomaly
comments_1: PHIBOT = p_b / rhoConst - g H(t), where p_b = hydrostatic ocean bottom pressure, rhoConst = reference density (1029 kg m-3), g is acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m s-2), and H(t) is model depth at time t. Units: p:[kg m-1 s-2], rhoConst:[kg m-3], g:[m s-2], H(t):[m]
comments_2: Note: includes atmospheric pressure loading. PHIBOT accounts for the model's time-varying grid cell thickness (z* coordinate system). PHIBOT is NOT corrected for global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH), and therefore should NOT be used for comparisons with ocean bottom pressure data. Instead, see OBPGMAP and OBP.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE > WATER PRESSURE

name: PHIHYD
long_name: Ocean hydrostatic pressure anomaly
comments_1: PHIHYD = p(k) / rhoConst - g z*(k,t), where p = hydrostatic ocean pressure at depth level k, rhoConst = reference density (1029 kg m-3), g is acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m s-2), and z*(k,t) is model depth at level k and time t. Units: p:[kg m-1 s-2], rhoConst:[kg m-3], g:[m s-2], H(t):[m].
comments_2: Note: includes atmospheric pressure loading. Quantity referred to in some contexts as hydrostatic pressure anomaly. PHIBOT accounts for the model's time-varying grid cell thickness (z* coordinate system). See PHIHYDcR for hydrostatic pressure potential anomaly calculated using time-invariant grid cell thicknesses. PHIHYD is NOT corrected for global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE > WATER PRESSURE

name: PHIHYDcR
long_name: Ocean hydrostatic pressure anomaly at constant depths
comments_1: PHIHYD = p(k) / rhoConst - g z(k,t), where p = hydrostatic ocean pressure at depth level k, rhoConst = reference density (1029 kg m-3), g is acceleration due to gravity (9.81 m s-2), and z(k,t) is fixed model depth at level k. Units: p:[kg m-1 s-2], rhoConst:[kg m-3], g:[m s-2], H(t):[m].
comments_2: Note: includes atmospheric pressure loading. Quantity referred to in some contexts as hydrostatic pressure potential anomaly. PHIHYDcR is calculated with respect to the model's initial, time-invariant grid cell thicknesses. See PHIHYD for hydrostatic pressure anomaly calculated using model's time-variable grid cell thicknesses (z* coordinate system). PHIHYDcR is is NOT corrected for global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN PRESSURE > WATER PRESSURE

name: RHOAnoma
long_name: In-situ seawater density anomaly
comments_1: In-situ seawater density anomaly relative to the reference density, rhoConst. rhoConst = 1029 kg m-3.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > DENSITY
internal note: INCLUDE HFACC FOR VOLUME MEAN CALCULATIONS

name: SALT
long_name: Salinity
comments_1: Defined using CF convention 'Sea water salinity is the salt content of sea water, often on the Practical Salinity Scale of 1978. However, the unqualified term 'salinity' is generic and does not necessarily imply any particular method of calculation. The units of salinity are dimensionless and the units attribute should normally be given as 1e-3 or 0.001 i.e. parts per thousand.' see https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SALINITY/DENSITY > SALINITY
internal note: INCLUDE HFACC FOR VOLUME MEAN CALCULATIONS

name: SFLUX
long_name: Rate of change of total ocean salinity per m2 accounting for mass fluxes.
comments_1: The rate of change of total ocean salinity due to freshwater fluxes across the liquid surface and the addition or removal of mass
comments_2: Note: the global area integral of SFLUX matches the time-derivative of total ocean salinity (psu s-1). Unlike oceFWflx, SFLUX includes the contribution to the total ocean salinity from changing ocean mass (e.g. from the addition or removal of freshwater in oceFWflx).

name: SIacSubl
long_name: Freshwater flux to the atmosphere due to sublimation-deposition of snow or ice
comments_1: Freshwater flux to the atmosphere due to sublimation-deposition of snow or ice
comments_2: Positive values imply sublimation from ice/snow to vapor, negative values imply deposition from atmospheric moisture
direction: >0 decreases snow or sea-ice thickness (HSNOW or HEFF)
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > ATMOSPHERIC WATER VAPOR > WATER VAPOR PROCESSES > SUBLIMATION

name: SIarea
long_name: Sea-ice concentration
comments_1: Fraction of ocean grid cell covered with sea-ice [0 to 1]. CF Standard Name Table v73:  'Area fraction' is the fraction of a grid cell's horizontal area that has some characteristic of interest. It is evaluated as the area of interest divided by the grid cell area. It may be expressed as a fraction, a percentage, or any other dimensionless representation of a fraction. Sea ice area fraction is area of the sea surface occupied by sea ice. It is also called 'sea ice concentration'. 'Sea ice' means all ice floating in the sea which has formed from freezing sea water, rather than by other processes such as calving of land ice to form icebergs. https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
comments_2: Defined using CF Standard Name Table v73: 'Area fraction' is the fraction of a grid cell's horizontal area that has some characteristic of interest. It is evaluated as the area of interest divided by the grid cell area. It may be expressed as a fraction, a percentage, or any other dimensionless representation of a fraction. Sea ice area fraction is area of the sea surface occupied by sea ice. It is also called 'sea ice concentration'. 'Sea ice' means all ice floating in the sea which has formed from freezing sea water and precipitation, rather than by other processes such as calving of land ice to form icebergs. https://cfconventions.org/Data/cf-standard-names/73/build/cf-standard-name-table.html
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE CONCENTRATION > ICE FRACTION, EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE CONCENTRATION
internal note: 1 is the CF convention's unit for dimensionless quantities

name: SIatmFW
long_name: Net freshwater flux into the open ocean, sea-ice, and snow
comments_1: Net freshwater flux into the combined liquid ocean, sea-ice, and snow reservoirs from the atmosphere and runoff.
comments_2: Note: freshwater fluxes BETWEEN the liquid ocean and sea-ice or snow reservoirs do not contribute to SIatmFW. SIatmFW counts all fluxes to/from the atmosphere that change the TOTAL freshwater stored in the combined liquid ocean, sea-ice, and snow reservoirs.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > FRESH WATER FLUX

name: SIatmQnt
long_name: Net upward heat flux to the atmosphere
comments_1: Net upward heat flux to the atmosphere across open water and sea-ice or snow surfaces.
comments_2: Note: nonzero SIatmQnt may not be associated with a change in ocean potential temperature due to sea-ice growth or melting. To calculate total ocean heat content changes use the variable TFLUX which also accounts for changing ocean mass (e.g. oceFWflx).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: sIceLoad
long_name: Average sea-ice and snow mass per unit area
comments_1: Total mass of sea-ice and snow in a model grid cell averaged over model grid cell area
comments_2: Note: sIceLoad is used to correct model sea level anomaly, ETAN, to calculate dynamic sea surface height, SSH, and sea surface height without the inverted barometer (IB correction), SSHNOIBC. In the model, sea-ice is treated as floating above the sea level with ETAN tracing the location of the ocean-ice interface. Consequently, sea-ice growth in the model lowers ETAN and sea-ice melting raises ETAN. Dynamic sea surface height is obtained by correcting ETAN by the weight of ice and snow directly above following Archimedes’ principle.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS, EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SNOW DEPTH

name: SIheff
long_name: Area-averaged sea-ice thickness
comments_1: Sea-ice thickness averaged over the entire model grid cell, including open water where sea-ice thickness is zero
comments_2: Note: sea-ice thickness over the ICE-COVERED fraction of the grid cell is SIheff/SIarea
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > ICE DEPTH/THICKNESS

name: SIhsnow
long_name: Area-averaged snow thickness
comments_1: Snow thickness averaged over the entire model grid cell, including open water where snow thickness is zero
comments_2: Note: snow thickness over the ICE-COVERED fraction of the grid cell is SIhsnow/SIarea
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SNOW DEPTH

name: SIsnPrcp
long_name: Snow precipitation on sea-ice
comments_1: Snow precipitation rate over sea-ice, averaged over the entire model grid cell.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > ATMOSPHERE > PRECIPITATION > SOLID PRECIPITATION > SNOW

name: SIaaflux
long_name: Conservative ocean and sea-ice advective heat flux adjustment
comments_1: Heat flux associated with the temperature difference between sea surface temperature and sea-ice (assume 0 degree C in the model)
comments_2: Note: heat flux needed to melt/freeze sea-ice at 0 degC to sea water at the ocean surface (at sea surface temperature), excluding the latent heat of fusion.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: SIfwThru
long_name: Precipitation through sea-ice
comments_1: Precipitation over sea-ice covered regions reaching ocean through sea-ice
comments_2: Note: Precipitation over sea-ice covered regions that directly reaches ocean through the sea-ice. It is not due to melt of sea-ice/snow.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > FRESH WATER FLUX

name: SIrsSubl
long_name: Residual sublimation freshwater flux
comments_1: Residual freshwater flux by sublimation to remove water from or add water to ocean. When implied sublimation freshwater flux SIacSubl is larger than availabe sea-ice/snow, SIrsSubl is positive and water is removed from ocean
comments_2: Note: freshwater flux by sublimation that is to remove water from the ocean when it is positive.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > FRESH WATER FLUX

name: SIuice
long_name: Sea-ice velocity in the model +x direction
comments_1: Horizontal sea-ice velocity in the +x direction at the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +SIuice(i_g,j) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: SIvice
long_name: Sea-ice velocity in the model +y direction
comments_1: Horizontal sea-ice velocity in the +y direction at the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +SIvice(i,j_g) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k=0). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > CRYOSPHERE > SEA ICE > SEA ICE MOTION

name: SSH
long_name: Dynamic sea surface height anomaly
comments_1: Dynamic sea surface height anomaly above the geoid, suitable for comparisons with altimetry sea surface height data products that apply the inverse barometer (IB) correction
comments_2: Note: SSH is calculated by correcting model sea level anomaly ETAN for three effects: a) global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH), b) the inverted barometer (IB) effect (see SSHIBC) and c) sea level displacement due to sea-ice and snow pressure loading (see sIceLoad). SSH can be compared with the similarly-named SSH variable in previous ECCO products that did not include atmospheric pressure loading (e.g., Version 4 Release 3). Use SSHNOIBC for comparisons with altimetry data products that do NOT apply the IB correction.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SEA SURFACE TOPOGRAPHY > SEA SURFACE HEIGHT

name: SSHIBC
long_name: The inverted barometer (IB) correction to sea surface height due to atmospheric pressure loading
comments_1: Not an SSH itself, but a correction to model sea level anomaly (ETAN) required to account for the static part of sea surface displacement by atmosphere pressure loading: SSH = SSHNOIBC - SSHIBC.
comments_2: Note: Use SSH for model-data comparisons with altimetry data products that DO apply the IB correction and SSHNOIBC for comparisons with altimetry data products that do NOT apply the IB correction.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SEA SURFACE TOPOGRAPHY > SEA SURFACE HEIGHT

name: SSHNOIBC
long_name: Sea surface height anomaly without the inverted barometer (IB) correction
comments_1: Sea surface height anomaly above the geoid without the inverse barometer (IB) correction, suitable for comparisons with altimetry sea surface height data products that do NOT apply the inverse barometer (IB) correction
comments_2: Note: SSHNOIBC is calculated by correcting model sea level anomaly ETAN for two effects: a) global mean steric sea level changes related to density changes in the Boussinesq volume-conserving model (Greatbatch correction, see sterGloH), b) sea level displacement due to sea-ice and snow pressure loading (see sIceLoad). In ECCO Version 4 Release 4 the model is forced with atmospheric pressure loading. SSHNOIBC does not correct for the static part of the effect of atmosphere pressure loading on sea surface height (the so-called inverse barometer (IB) correction). Use SSH for comparisons with altimetry data products that DO apply the IB correction.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > SEA SURFACE TOPOGRAPHY > SEA SURFACE HEIGHT

name: TFLUX
long_name: Rate of change of ocean heat content per m2 accounting for mass fluxes.
comments_1: The rate of change of ocean heat content due to heat fluxes across the liquid surface and the addition or removal of mass.
comments_2: Note: the global area integral of TFLUX and geothermal flux (geothermalFlux.bin) matches the time-derivative of ocean heat content (J/s). Unlike oceQnet, TFLUX includes the contribution to the ocean heat content from changing ocean mass (e.g. from oceFWflx).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN HEAT BUDGET > HEAT FLUX

name: THETA
long_name: Potential temperature
comments_1: Sea water potential temperature is the temperature a parcel of sea water would have if moved adiabatically to sea level pressure.
comments_2: Note: the equation of state is a modified UNESCO formula by Jackett and McDougall (1995), which uses the model variable potential temperature as input assuming a horizontally and temporally constant pressure of $p_0=-g ho_{0} z$.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN TEMPERATURE > POTENTIAL TEMPERATURE

name: UVEL
long_name: Horizontal velocity in the model +x direction
comments_1: Horizontal velocity in the +x direction at the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +UVEL(i_g,j,k) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Do NOT use UVEL for volume flux calculations because the model's grid cell thicknesses vary with time (z* coordinates); use UVELMASS instead. Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. See EVEL and NVEL for zonal and meridional velocity.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS
internal note: INCLUDE HFACW FOR VOLUME MEAN CALCULATIONS

name: VVEL
long_name: Horizontal velocity in the model +y direction
comments_1: Horizontal velocity in the +y direction at the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +VVEL(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Do NOT use VVEL for volume flux calculations because the model's grid cell thicknesses vary with time (z* coordinates); use VVELMASS instead. Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. See EVEL and NVEL for zonal and meridional velocity.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS
internal note: INCLUDE HFACS FOR VOLUME MEAN CALCULATIONS

name: WVEL
long_name: Vertical velocity
comments_1: Vertical velocity in the +z direction at the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +WVEL(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z motion through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). WVEL is identical to WVELMASS.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS
internal note: wvel is the same as wvel mass. wvel, uvel, and vvel are grouped in the 'ocean velocity' dataset. wvelmass, uvelmass, and vvelmass are grouped in the 'ocean volume fluxes' dataset.

name: UVELMASS
long_name: Horizontal velocity in the model +x direction per unit area of the grid cell 'u' face
comments_1: Horizontal velocity in the model +x direction averaged over the area of the tracer grid cell 'u' face on the native model grid ('u' grid cell face area = drF dyG). Accounts for partial cells (hFacW < 1) and for time-varying grid cell thickness (z* coordinate system). Volume flux in +x = UVELMASS drF dyG.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +UVELMASS(i,j,k) corresponds to +x fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). UVELMASS can be used for volume flux calculations because it accounts for the grid cell thicknesses variations in the +x direction (hFacW) with time (z* coordinate system). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. See VVELMASS and WVELMASS
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS

name: VVELMASS
long_name: Horizontal velocity in the model +y direction per unit area of the grid cell 'v' face
comments_1: Horizontal velocity in the model +y direction averaged over the area of the tracer grid cell 'v' face on the native model grid ('v' grid cell face area = drF dxG). Accounts for partial cells (hFacS < 1) and for time-varying grid cell thickness (z* coordinate system). Volume flux in +y = VVELMASS drF dxG.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +VVELMASS(i,j,k) corresponds to +y fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). VVELMASS can be used for volume flux calculations because it accounts for grid cell thicknesses variations in the +y direction (hFacS) with time (z* coordinate system). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. See UVELMASS and WVELMASS.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS

name: WVELMASS
long_name: Grid cell face-averaged vertical velocity in the model +z direction.
comments_1: Vertical velocity in the +z direction at the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid. Volume flux in +z = WVELMASS drA.
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +WVELMASS(i,j,k) corresponds to upward +z motion through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Unlike UVELMASS and VVELMASS, WVELMASS is not scaled by a time-varying open water fraction because the open water fraction of the 'w' face is always 1, thus WVELMASS is identical to WVEL.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS
internal note: INCLUDE DEPTH SO PEOPLE KNOW WHERE BOTTOM IS?

name: UVELSTAR
long_name: Gent-McWilliams velocity in the model +x direction scaled by time-varying grid cell thickness
comments_1: Gent-McWilliams horizontal velocity in the +x direction at the 'u' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: UVELSTAR is not a model diagnostic but is calculated offline: UVELSTAR = -d/dz GM_PsiX. In the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +UVELSTAR(i_g,j,k) corresponds to +x tracer fluxes through the 'u' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. See EVELSTAR and NVELSTAR.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS

name: VVELSTAR
long_name: Gent-McWilliams velocity in the model +y direction scaled by time-varying grid cell thickness
comments_1: Gent-McWilliams horizontal velocity in the +y direction at the 'v' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: VVELSTAR is not a model diagnostic but is calculated offline: VVELSTAR = -d/dz GM_PsiY. In the Arakawa-C grid, horizontal velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +VVELSTAR(i,j_g,k) corresponds to +y tracer fluxes through the 'v' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k). Also, the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles. See EVELSTAR and NVELSTAR.
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS

name: WVELSTAR
long_name: Gent-McWilliams velocity in the model +z direction
comments_1: Gent-McWilliams vertical bolus velocity in the +z direction at the top 'w' face of the tracer cell on the native model grid
comments_2: Note: in the Arakawa-C grid, vertical velocities are staggered relative to the tracer cells with indexing such that +WVELSTAR(i,j,k_l) corresponds to upward +z motion through the top 'w' face of the tracer cell at (i,j,k).
GCMD_keywords: EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION, EARTH SCIENCE > OCEANS > OCEAN CIRCULATION > OCEAN CURRENTS

name: Um_dPHdx
long_name: Momentum tendency in the model +x direction
comments_1: Momentum tendency in the +x direction due to the hydrostatic pressure gradient at the 'u' face of the native model grid cell
comments_2: Note: the model +x direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical east-west direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.

name: Vm_dPHdy
long_name: Momentum tendency in the model +y direction
comments_1: Momentum tendency in the +y direction due to the hydrostatic pressure gradient at the 'v' face of the native model grid cell
comments_2: Note: the model +y direction does not necessarily correspond to the geographical north-south direction because the x and y axes of the model's curvilinear lat-lon-cap (llc) grid have arbitrary orientations which vary within and across tiles.
